evidence: sampling is essentially a point-wise multiplication of the signal with an impulse train.
this operation in the spatial domain has a direct consequence in the frequency domain.
Multiplying by an impulse train in space corresponds to replicating the spectrum of the signal.
we also obtain periodicity in frequency.
when you multiply the continuous signal by this impulse train, the result is a set of discrete values.
Imagine you have a continuous signal - shown on the left. To sample this signal, what we're really doing is multiplying it by a train of impulses.

And here's the key idea: this operation in the spatial domain has a direct consequence in the frequency domain. Multiplying by an impulse train in space corresponds to replicating the spectrum of the signal - creating a periodic train of delta functions in the frequency domain.
To sample this signal, what we’re really doing is multiplying it by a train of impulses.
In the spatial domain, sampling is essentially a point-wise multiplication of the signal with an impulse train.
Multiplying by an impulse train in space corresponds to replicating the spectrum of the signal - creating a periodic train of delta functions in the frequency domain.
